snippet.title: Sharks back from brink and firing ahead of finals
snippet.content: RUGBY LEAGUE: Coach Glenn Irwin admits he had given up on his team six weeks ago but now he's relishing the prospect of finals footy. Caloundra is third on the six-team Sunshine Coast division one ladder through 18 of 19 rounds after dropping just one of its past five games. A 52-14 thrashing of Nambour at Shark Park on Saturday enhanced the team's claims and confirmed it will host the minor-semi-final in the four-team play-offs. The team's form is a far cry from its mid-season woes, when it lost five in a row. "Six weeks ago I didn't think we'd win another game. We were terrible," Irwin said. "You could've dropped us back to reserve grade and we wouldn't have a game there. "But we've won a couple in a row now ... we've got a bit of a spring in our step." Irwin was unsure what caused the turnaround. "We did have key players out (mid-season) and we've just about got everyone back now. "But if I knew exactly what the answer was we'd win every week and I'd bottle it. "The last two weeks the boys have played better together as a team. It was really obvious, with their body language. They were very upbeat." Liam and Chris Ainsworth scored five tries between them in the 10-tries-to-three display against the last-placed Crushers. "I know Nambour is struggling with players but they still had Marty Cordwell and Donald Malone," Irwin said. Harrison Langer, the son of Queensland legend Allan, has enjoyed a strong season but on Saturday suffered a suspected fractured toe. Maroochydore and Kawana have locked up first and second place respectively. The Swans beat Caboolture 28-14 at Buderim and Kawana beat Noosa 26-12 at Tewantin.
